data.title: The Broken Horseshoe (1953)
data.meta_description: When a hit and run patient is murdered an attending doctor is placed under suspicion.
data.text:
When a hit and run patient is murdered, an attending doctor is placed under immediate suspicion in this action drama directed by Martyn C. Webster.

The story concerns a doctor who operates on a man who is hurt in a hit and run incident, but when the patient is later murdered, he finds himself accused of committing the crime. A mysterious woman with a link to the real killers decides to help him clear his name and get rid of the criminals' drug ring.

Robert Beatty plays the role of Mark Fenton, the doctor operating on the patient who suddenly finds himself accused of murdering the patient. He knows he didn’t do it, so if he didn’t, who did?

Elizabeth…

A tiny budget is evident in every scene of this otherwise effective liitle thriller in which surgeon Robert Beatty finds himself suspected of murder after a patient he operated on is murdered. Elizabeth Sellars is the mysterious beauty he falls for, and the film's biggest strength is that it uses our preconceptions to completely wrongfoot us about the part she plays in the murder.

The Broken Horseshoe was the first ever thriller serial aired by the BBC. Made in 1952, it starred John Robinson (who would go on to play the lead in Nigel Kneale's TV series Quatermass II following original actor Reginald Tate's death) and was written by Frances Durbridge. Broadcast live in six half hour parts on Saturday evenings, no recording was ever made of this story of a gallant doctor who stumbles upon a vicious horse-doping ring, so modern audiences cannot say how good it actually was.

Which is where this film adaptation comes in. What a lot of people forget is that it was actually quite common practice back in the day to take a successful TV serial and remake…
